docs.lead_paragraph: JEFF WALSH of Rockville, a member of the 143rd Military Police Company of the Connecticut National Guard, was on his way home from a wedding in New York the afternoon of Sept. 29 when he got a call from his unit commander to report for guard duty at Groton-New London Airport the next morning at 4 a.m. He managed to get only a couple of hours sleep before rising at 1:30 the next morning to get ready and make the trip. He called and left a message on the answering machine at New England Building Products, where he works installing gutters on new homes. He knows this is a busy time of year for the company, because so many contractors are putting the finishing touches on homes built over the summer, but no one could control the timing, he said with a shrug.

headline.main: While They're Protecting Us, Who's Protecting Them?

docs.abstract: Article on workers across Connecticut, called up for emergency National Guard and Reserve duties, who face possible loss of jobs and wages; while federal law requires companies to hire workers back when they return, it is up to companies to determine how and whether to pay them while on duty; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Marie Cigich, a daughter of Betty Durst of Clearwater, Fla., and the late Donald R. Durst, was married yesterday to Ted Greenberg, the son of Alan C. Greenberg of Manhattan and the late Ann Greenberg. Judge Shirley Werner Kornreich of the Civil Court in Manhattan officiated at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Kathryn Olson Greenberg. Mrs. Greenberg, 33, is the director of a school-based mental health screening program in Manhattan and the Bronx for the department of child and adolescent psychiatry at Columbia University. She graduated from Florida State University, received a master's degree in psychology from Southern Connecticut State University and is a candidate for a master's degree in social work at Columbia.

docs.lead_paragraph: A NEW law took effect in the state on Oct. 1 that bolsters nursing mothers' rights in the workplace. The law requires that employers provide employees who are nursing mothers with a private place -- other than a toilet stall -- to express milk for their babies. It was passed with no significant opposition as women's groups, unions and many employers supported the legislation's goals of protecting the health of babies and promoting employee productivity and loyalty.

headline.main: For Nursing Mothers, Their Own Space

docs.abstract: Article on new law in Connecticut, effective October 1, that requires employers to provide workers who are nursing mothers with private place, other than toilet stall, to breast feed their babies; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS autumn leaves litter walkways and mild breezes give way to brisk dawns, there is another unmistakable sign that a change of seasons is upon the State House: the steady buzz of résumés grinding through fax machines. For the first time since the 1989, an incumbent governor in New Jersey is not waging a campaign to remain in office, leaving a power vacuum that will quickly begin to fill up after the November election. It will signal a clear change in the way business is conducted -- who is important, who is not and who will get the lucrative state contracts.
docs.abstract: Article on palpable feeling of shift in power in New Jersey as, for first time since 1989, incumbent governor is not waging campaign and candidates are focusing on forming new cabinet; some fear Bret Schundler will stack cabinet with conservative Republicans while others say cabinet under James McGreevey will be controlled by Democratic power brokers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Corinne Lise Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Miller of North Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to Kevin Randolph Smithen, the son of Marcia Cohen of Katonah, N.Y., and Dr. Charles Smithen of New York. Rabbi Matthew Simon officiated at the Omni Shoreham Hotel in Washington. Mrs. Smithen, 31, is a senior manager for advertising and promotion partnerships at iWon.com, an Internet portal in New York. She graduated from Emory University and received an M.B.A. from George Washington University. Her father is an independent broker of life and health insurance in North Bethesda.

docs.lead_paragraph: SOUVENIR stands were shuttered for the season and the mighty Cyclone stood silent, but last Sunday, Coney Island still had customers not yet ready to surrender summer's pleasures. Parents waved at children on kiddie rides, and Deno's Wonder Wheel, the 150-foot-high Ferris wheel, was still spinning, its blue and orange spokes bright against a slate-gray sky. In late afternoon, Alexandra Katherine Mann and Stuart Yves Weger had the wheel temporarily stilled as they exchanged rings, their gently swaying car just inches off the ground. Inside the car, Rabbi Abigail Sosland talked cheerfully with the couple -- and by microphone to the assembled crowd -- about how life goes around and around and has its ups and downs.
docs.abstract: Alexandra Katherine Mann and Stuart Yves Weger are wed aboard Coney Island's Wonder Wheel; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Revolution Avenue the bars are all but empty, the restaurants and mariachis are quiet, the tourists are scarce, and the Cipro is rapidly changing hands. Hand-drawn posters fill pharmacy windows with eerie reminders of the fears that draw many shoppers across the border here. ''We have Cipro,'' the signs read. ''Highly effective against anthrax.''

headline.main: Sí, We Have Cipro; the Panicky and the Profiteers Head to Mexico

docs.abstract: Sales of Ciprofloxacin, antibiotic used to treat anthrax, are soaring at Mexican pharmacies as Americans cross border to buy drug without prescription at low prices; many buy dozens of bottles at time, apparently for resale at profit in United States; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Retirees will receive $22 more a month next year, on average, in their Social Security checks because of the moderate rise in inflation this year. The higher benefits, a 2.6 percent cost-of-living increase, reflect the modest growth of the Consumer Price Index for the 12 months through September, the time span used by the government to calculate annual changes in Social Security payments. Monthly Social Security checks for 45.6 million Americans are adjusted annually to keep rising prices from eroding recipients' benefits.

headline.main: Social Security Checks to Rise 2.6%, an Average of $22 a Month

docs.abstract: Retirees will receive $22 more per month in 2002, on average, in their Social Security checks because of moderate rise in inflation this year; higher benefits, 2.6 percent cost-of-living increase, reflect modest growth of Consumer Price Index for 12 months through September; monthly Medicare premiums will increase $4 per month next year to $54, an 8 percent increase; Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.4 percent in September (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The government passed a bill giving 400,000 prostitutes working rights and removing the stigma from their profession. Starting next year, sex workers will have the right to unemployment benefits, retraining for jobs, health insurance and a pension. Prostitutes will also be legally entitled to turn away customers and sue them if they refuse to pay for their services. Victor Homola (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lifting Status Of Prostitutes

docs.abstract: German government passes bill giving 400,000 prostitutes working rights and removing stigma from their profession (S)
